newsitem.title: USA: Court rules Stockpile cobalt sale within authority.
newsitem.headline: Court rules Stockpile cobalt sale within authority.

text.p: Judge Tidwell of the U.S. Court of Federal Claims has ruled that U.S. Stockpile did have authority to carry out sales of cobalt in the way it did, but he was concerned about the agency's use of domestic preference price matching in sealed bid sales, a Stockpile attorney said.
Judge Tidwell issued his written ruling on Tuesday.
It stemmed from a clutch of complaints to the court by Minor Metals Inc about Stockpile's handling of cobalt sales.
"We have the authority to do what we did, but he (Judge Tidwell) does not like the way we did it," Stockpile attorney Essie Schloss said.
"He has not recommended anything, and it's up to us how we deal with it, he says," Schloss added.
Tidwell has asked Stockpile to report back to him by June 13. "We will report back and figure out what to do from there," Schloss said.

Tidwell was concerned about the use of domestic preference clause in a sealed bid sale which allows a bidder, who will use the cobalt domestically, to later match a price offered by a bidder who wanted to export the metal.
The prohibition of "all or none" clauses in sealed bids was considered legal by the judge, Schloss said.
Stockpile cobalt sales have been suspended since March.
